results.headline: As Murkiness Descends, Ghosts Grow Restless

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Eclipse

results.summary_short: A romance (and a tragedy) has a pinch of the supernatural.

results.headline: A New Life in Ballet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dancing Across Borders

results.summary_short: Even if you don’t know your pliés from your battements frappés, the dance sequences in “Dancing Across Borders” are a delight.

results.headline: Love Triangle Devised by a Wary Wife

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chloe

results.summary_short: A prostitute stirs up chaos in the life of a married couple.

results.headline: A Return to Neil Young’s Stage
results.display_title: Neil Young Trunk Show: Scenes From a Concert

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neil Young Trunk Show: Scenes From a Concert

results.summary_short: Beautifully lighted and meticulously recorded, “Neil Young Trunk Show” looks and sounds like several million bucks.

results.headline: Il Duce as Young Lover: The Making of a Dictator

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vincere

results.summary_short: “Vincere” is a sustained, alternatingly exhausting and aesthetically exhilarating howl of a film.

results.headline: Why Even Bother Trying to Connect?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greenberg

results.summary_short: “Greenberg” is the funniest and saddest movie Noah Baumbach has made so far, and also the riskiest.

results.headline: Proving Their Mettle in the Men-Only Era of Rock

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Runaways

results.summary_short: “The Runaways” evokes its moment and milieu with affectionate, almost uncanny fidelity.

results.headline: Life Under a Tyrant, Even After Escaping

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kimjongilia

results.summary_short: “Kimjongilia” is built around interviews with more than a half-dozen North Koreans who fled their country but can’t shake its hold on their imaginations.

results.headline: A Hands-On Approach to Health Care Reform

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Repo Men

results.summary_short: To audiences starved for quasi-medical gore, the gruesome “Repo Men” should help fill the void left by “Nip/Tuck.”

results.headline: The Universe Up There

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hubble 3D

results.summary_short: “Hubble 3D” is dazzling to look at of course. But such ponderous, cliché-heavy narration.

results.headline: Hacker With Ink on Back and Big Chip on Shoulder
results.display_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

results.summary_short: In “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” Noomi Rapace more or less looks the part that the filmmakers don’t let her fully play.

results.headline: Lost in Social Minefields Without a Proper Clue

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diary of a Wimpy Kid

results.summary_short: In “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” episodes that might be howlingly funny on the page turn weirdly gross and sadistic on screen.

results.headline: A Bronx Tale, With Bait

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of City Island

results.summary_short: “City Island” is a professionally executed farce of the yelling-family variety.

results.headline: In a Battle of the Exes, the Punches Are Pulled

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bounty Hunter

results.summary_short: “The Bounty Hunter” is the latest evidence that, when it comes to romantic combat, we live in a more thoughtlessly brutal age than our ancestors did.

results.headline: One Man, Four Women and a Roman Holiday

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mid-August Lunch

results.summary_short: Gianni Di Gregorio’s luminous sliver of a film, “Mid-August Lunch,” is a Chekhovian vignette about the joys and regrets of old age and the pleasures of sociability.

results.headline: Fleshing Out Life in Remote China

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Town

results.summary_short: Zhao Dayong’s documentary is a nearly three-hour-long visit to a remote Chinese mountain village.

results.headline: Fierce Love: Better Not Make This Mom Angry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mother

results.summary_short: A son’s arrest for murder leads to a parent’s crusade in “Mother.”

results.headline: A Search for That Casualty, Truth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Green Zone

results.summary_short: In “Green Zone,” action under pressure is a test and a revelation of character.

results.headline: Domestic Dramedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White on Rice

results.summary_short: “White on Rice” is an Asian-American domestic dramedy that’s determined to be as culture-neutral as possible.

results.headline: More Than Words

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tales From The Script

results.summary_short: In Peter Hanson’s dishy documentary “Tales From the Script,” 46 screenwriters gab agreeably about the tribulations of their profession.
